Description: The SEC announced settled enforcement actions against seven broker-dealers for failing to disclose they had received payments for providing research coverage of certain public companies, in violation of Section 17(b) of the Securities Act of 1933.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that broker-dealer Janney Montgomery Scott LLC would pay $850,000 to settle allegations that it failed to establish and enforce policies and procedures to prevent the misuse of material, nonpublic information.

Private Litigation Case Title: FAHRY v. JANNEY MONTGOMERY SCOTT, LLC et al

Company: The Penn Mutual Life Insurance Co.
Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into consent orders with six life insurance companies to resolve alleged violations of New York Insurance Regulations in deferred to immediate annuity replacement transactions.  The insurers, collectively, agreed  to pay $1,152,154 in restitution and $673,000 in penalties.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
Pennsylvania Department of Banking and Securities

Description: employment of an unlicensed investment adviser
Agency: Rhode Island Department of Business Regulation

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered five firms to pay restitution estimated at more than $18 million, including interest, to affected customers for failing to waive mutual fund sales charges for eligible charitable organizations and retirement accounts.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority entered into final settlements with four firms to settle charges relating to the sale of Auction Rate Securities (ARS) that became illiquid when auctions froze in February 2008.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD fined Janney Montgomery Scott LLC $1.2 million for permitting improper market timing and related violations. In addition, NASD ordered the firm to pay nearly $1 million in restitution to the affected mutual funds.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Agency: Connecticut Securities and Business Investments Division
